title: 106_hr1165
content: The Act may be cited as the "Black Canyon National Park and Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area Act of 1999". Congress finds that Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Monument was established for the preservation of its spectacular gorges and additional features of scenic, scientific, and educational interest. The area includes unique ecological, geological, scenic, historical, and wildlife components, providing opportunities for educational and recreational activities. Adjacent public land downstream of the monument also has wilderness value and offers unique resources for scientific, educational, and recreational purposes. The public and private land surrounding Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Monument contributes to protecting wildlife, scenic qualities, and recreational opportunities. Designating this land as a national park would provide greater long-term protection and expanded visitor use opportunities. The area offers exceptional multiple use opportunities and natural, cultural value. The area surrounding Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Monument is known for its natural, cultural, scenic, wilderness, and recreational resources. It is worthy of additional protection as a national conservation area, including the Gunnison Gorge as part of the national wilderness system. SEC. 3. DEFINITIONS. This Act defines key terms such as Conservation Area, Map, Park, and Secretary. SEC. 4. ESTABLISHMENT OF BLACK CANYON NATIONAL PARK. Establishment of Black Canyon National Park in Colorado, as depicted on the Map, with the termination of the Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Monument designation and incorporation of its land into the new park. The Map is available for public inspection at the National Park Service offices. Black Canyon National Park in Colorado includes land within the Black Canyon of the Gunnison National Monument boundary and any additional land transferred by the Bureau of Land Management. References to the Monument are now references to the Park, and funds allocated for the Monument are now available for the Park's purposes. The Secretary shall manage Black Canyon National Park, including grazing permissions, in accordance with relevant laws. The Secretary will prepare a grazing management plan for grazing activities within Black Canyon National Park. SEC. 5. ACQUISITION OF PROPERTY AND MINOR BOUNDARY ADJUSTMENTS. The Secretary may acquire land for the Park through donation, transfer, purchase, or exchange with owner consent. After acquisition, the Secretary will revise the Park's boundary to include the new land and administer it according to laws and regulations. The Secretary will conduct an official boundary survey of the Park within 5 years of the Act's enactment. Hunting may be allowed on privately owned land within the Park, with restrictions set by the Secretary. Once the Secretary acquires fee ownership of the land, hunting authority on that land will cease. Expansion of the Black Canyon of the Gunnison Wilderness to include approximately 4,460 acres as "Tract A" and administration as part of the Park. Establishment of the Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area. The Gunnison Gorge National Conservation Area, spanning 57,725 acres, is established to be managed by the Secretary of the Bureau of Land Management to protect its resources in accordance with relevant laws. Federal land within the area is withdrawn from various forms of use and disposal. The Secretary shall permit hunting, trapping, and fishing within the Conservation Area in accordance with applicable laws. The Secretary may issue regulations designating zones where no hunting or trapping is permitted for reasons concerning public safety, administration, or public use and enjoyment. Additionally, motorized vehicles can be used on established roadways within the area. The use of motorized vehicles in the Conservation Area is allowed if compatible with off-highway vehicle designations or practicable under a management plan. The Secretary must develop a comprehensive plan for long-term protection and management of the area within 4 years of enactment. The plan for the Conservation Area must describe appropriate uses and management in consultation with various agencies, may incorporate existing plans, and must be prepared within 4 years of enactment. The Secretary may revise the boundary of the Conservation Area after acquiring land necessary for its designated purposes. Designation of wilderness within the conservation area is specified in Section 8. Within the Conservation Area, the Gunnison Gorge Wilderness is designated as wilderness, covering approximately 17,700 acres. A 300-acre portion exempt from the wilderness study area is incorporated into the Conservation Area. The wilderness areas designated under this Act within the Conservation Area shall be administered by the Secretary in accordance with the Wilderness Act. State of Colorado retains jurisdiction over wildlife and fish on public land within the State. SEC. 9. WITHDRAWAL. The land identified as tract B on the Map, approximately 1,554 acres, is withdrawn from all forms of entry, appropriation, disposal under public land laws, mining laws, and mineral leasing laws. SEC. 10. WATER RIGHTS. SEC. 10. WATER RIGHTS. This section clarifies that the Act does not reserve water for any purpose or affect existing water rights. Any new water rights needed will be established according to Colorado state laws. The Secretary will conduct a study on land protection and open space in and around the Curecanti National Recreation Area, assessing natural, cultural, recreational, and scenic resources, identifying alternatives for protection, and recommending economically feasible options. The Secretary will recommend economically feasible tools and estimate costs for achieving the purposes outlined in the study. A report containing findings and recommendations will be submitted to Congress within 3 years. Additionally, recommendations for actions regarding the described land will be made to Congress. The Secretary may acquire additional land and interests before completing the study. The Secretary may acquire private land totaling approximately 1,065 acres through donation, purchase, or exchange with owner consent. Boundary revisions may occur after acquisition. Following land acquisition, the Secretary will revise the boundary of the Curecanti National Recreation Area to include the new land and administer it according to relevant laws and regulations. Authorization of appropriations is granted to carry out this Act.
